intro: Hesperodoria scopulorum, commonly known as the rock dandelion, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of numerous small florets. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils, often in arid or semi-arid environments. Its leaves are generally basal, with a rough or hairy texture, and the flowers are yellow, resembling those of the dandelion. Hesperodoria scopulorum is adapted to withstand drought and poor soil conditions, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
